ARABIC: بَلِ ٱدَّٰرَكَ عِلْمُهُمْ فِى ٱلْءَاخِرَةِ بَلْ هُمْ فِى شَكٍّ مِّنْهَا بَلْ هُم مِّنْهَا عَمُونَ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: No, their knowledge stoos short of the Next World. In fact they have doubts about it. In fact they are blind to it.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: Still less do they comprehend the life to come. In fact they are in doubt about it. Still more, they are blind to it."
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: Nay, but they have lost their knowledge of the Hereafter. They are steeped in doubt and uncertainty about it: rather they are blind to it.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: Their knowledge of the next life is no more than doubts. In fact, they are blind about it.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: Has their knowledge advanced so much as to know the Hereafter? On the contrary, they are in doubt concerning it; in fact they are blind towards it.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: Nay, their knowledge will perceive that in the Hereafter. Nay, they are in doubt about it. Nay, they are in complete blindness about it.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: Nay, their knowledge respecting the hereafter is slight and hasty; nay, they are in doubt about it; nay, they are quite blind to it
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: nay, but their knowledge fails as to the Hereafter; nay, they are in doubt of it; nay, they are blind to it.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: Nay, but doth their knowledge reach to the Hereafter? Nay, for they are in doubt concerning it. Nay, for they cannot see it.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: Indeed, their knowledge of the life to come stops short of the truth: they are [often] in doubt as to its reality: in fact, they are blind to it.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: Aye! their knowledge attaineth not to the Hereafter, Aye! they are in doubt thereof. Aye! thereunto they are blind.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: Do they comprehend the knowledge of the Hereafter? No, they are in doubt about it. Indeed, they are blind to it.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: Still less can their knowledge comprehend the Hereafter: Nay, they are in doubt and uncertainty thereanent; nay, they are blind thereunto!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Nay, they have no knowledge of the Hereafter. Nay, they are in doubt about it. Nay, they are blind about it.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: No, their knowledge fails them as to the Everlasting Life; no, they are in doubt about it, no, they are blind to it.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: In fact, their knowledge of the Hereafter is confused. In fact, they are in doubt about it. In fact, they are blind to it.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: Rather, their knowledge is arrested concerning the Hereafter. Rather, they are in doubt about it. Rather, they are, concerning it, blind.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [27:66] Nay, has their knowledge come to comprise (read adraka, similar to the [4th verbal] form akrama, ‘he was kind to’; a variant reading has iddāraka, which is actually tadāraka, with the tā’ changed into a dāl and assimilated with the [other] dāl, and a conjunctive hamza added, meaning, ‘attained’ or ‘caught up with’) the Hereafter?, such that they [have reason to] ask about the time of its coming — not so: Nay, for they are in doubt of it. Rather they are blind to it (‘amūna, ‘blind’, as in blindness of the heart; this [statement] is rhetorically more powerful than the preceding one; the origin [of the term] is ‘amiyūn, but the damma vowel is deemed too heavy for the yā’ and has been moved to the mīm, after dropping its kasra vowel).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (Nay, but doth their knowledge reach to the Hereafter) their knowledge is in consensus that there is no Hereafter? (Nay, for they are in doubt concerning it) concerning the coming of the Hour. (Nay, for they cannot see it) they are blind, unable to see.
